comments:
I create a new PDE project fill in the project name, accept the defaults, select Plugin with a view as the template, accept the defaults and create the project. I go to the Overview page and click on the Export Wizard link. I fill in the target directory /usr/local/eclipse where I have Eclipse installed and accept the defaults. The wizard creates a jar file in /usr/local/eclipse/plugins with my project name. I then exit eclipse and restart using the -clean option. Eclipse starts with no problem, but when I select Window->Show View->Other->Sample Category->Sample View the view is opened with the error message:

Unable to create view: Plug-in com.proxymetry.viewer was unable to load class com.proxymetry.viewer.views.SampleView.

The trace from the .log file is:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.equinox.registry 4 1 2006-09-15 13:36:34.984
!MESSAGE Unable to create view ID com.proxymetry.viewer.views.SampleView: Plug-in com.proxymetry.viewer was unable to load class com.proxymetry.viewer.views.SampleView.
!STACK 0

If I exit eclipse, remove the jar file, restart eclipse and click on the "Launch an Eclipse application" link on the Overview page for the project it launches a new Eclipse window and the view can be selected from Window-Show View->Others...etc with no problem. The Sample View is produced with the three entries it should have.

I have tried including the /bin directory in the build and defining the classpath to include it, but that did not help. I also tried importing additional packages, but that did not help either.

The problem is very repeatable.

This is not a development-time issue.  

Moving to Equinox.
My guess is your Bundle-ClassPath header is incorrect in your bundle manifest file.  Please paste the content of the META-INF/MANIFEST.MF file from the built jar.  Thanks.

Here is the MANIFEST.MF from the jar. It looks the same as the MANIFEST.MF created by the PDE Wizard. No mention of classpath at all.

Manifest-Version: 1.0
Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2
Bundle-Name: Viewer Plug-in
Bundle-SymbolicName: com.proxymetry.viewer; singleton:=true
Bundle-Version: 1.0.0
Bundle-Activator: com.proxymetry.viewer.Activator
Bundle-Vendor: PROXYMETRY
Bundle-Localization: plugin
Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui,
 org.eclipse.core.runtime
Eclipse-LazyStart: true

I added a Bundle-Classpath entry to the MANIFEST.MF so that it now looks like this, but it did not make any difference. I still get the CNFE.

Manifest-Version: 1.0
Bundle-ManifestVersion: 2
Bundle-Name: Viewer Plug-in
Bundle-SymbolicName: com.proxymetry.viewer; singleton:=true
Bundle-Version: 1.0.0
Bundle-Activator: com.proxymetry.viewer.Activator
Bundle-Vendor: PROXYMETRY
Bundle-Localization: plugin
Require-Bundle: org.eclipse.ui,
 org.eclipse.core.runtime
Eclipse-LazyStart: true
Bundle-ClassPath: .
Please attach the bundle.  I don't see anything obvious that should cause it to fail.

Created an attachment (id=50327)
jar file produced by eclipse export wizard

The bundle you requested.

It looks like you compiled the bundle with 1.5 compiler settings but are trying to run the bundle on a 1.4 VM.  When I run the bundle on a 1.4 VM I get the following error in the error log:

Wassim, this seems like a pretty common mistake.  Did the default compiler settings change in 3.2?

The fault was on my end. The link to the JRE on my system had been reset to point to a 1.4 VM. Probably something I installed reset it. This can happen pretty easily to anyone and is not obvious so it should be added to an FAQ for the PDE and RCP. Thanks Thomas and Wassim.

Tom, I believe JDT did change their compiler compliance default options in 3.2.

If you launch with a 1.5 JRE, the default compliance is now set to 1.5.

Since many people are not aware of the importance of the Java > Compiler preference page as they never had to worry about it in the past, this problem has become more common.
FYI - JDTCore did not change the compiler defaults. However, the JRE support is trying to adapt compiler settings to detected installed JREs. Darin is the man for this feature.

Reducing severity. I'm not sure there is anything left for us to do here.  Philippe, did you want Darin to do anything here?

FWIW fixes in bug 135885 now allow the ClassFormatError to propagate.  This allows the UI to display the ClassFormatError instead of a ClassNotFoundException that gives no context or reason for the exception.
Moving to PDE-UI for closure or suggestions for "automatically" fixing up the compiler settings.  This is not a Framework issue.

PDE does not trade in setting compiler defaults depending on JRE settings.

As per comment 10, moving to jdt/debug as they own the JRE area to resolve as appropriate.
Marking as Won't fix. We intentionally set the default compliace based on the detected VM.

traces.message: The activator com.proxymetry.viewer.Activator for bundle com.proxymetry.viewer is invalid
